blocks.text: Zero‑day vulnerabilities are unknown to vendors and therefore lack available patches at the time attackers exploit them. Because defenders cannot rely on traditional signature‑based detection, these flaws present significant challenges.

Advanced attackers often discover zero‑day vulnerabilities through independent research or by purchasing exploits from underground markets. These vulnerabilities may be used sparingly to avoid detection.
Indicators of zero‑day exploitation are often indirect, such as unusual system behavior or previously unseen attack patterns. Detection depends heavily on behavioral monitoring and anomaly detection.
Rapid containment and incident response are critical when zero‑day attacks are suspected, as prevention options are limited until patches become available.
